1061.original:
H-0273.1
HOUSE BILL 1061
State of Washington
69th Legislature
2025 Regular Session
ByRepresentatives Low and Jacobsen
Prefiled 12/13/24.Read first time 01/13/25.Referred to Committee on Transportation.
AN ACT Relating to providing additional parking flexibility in residential neighborhoods; and amending RCW 46.61.570.
BE IT ENACTED BY THE LEGISLATURE OF THE STATE OF WASHINGTON:
Sec. 1. RCW 46.61.570 and 1977 ex.s. c 151 s 40 are each amended to read as follows:
(1) Except when necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic, or in compliance with law or the directions of a police officer or official traffic control device, no person shall:
(a) Stop, stand, or park a vehicle:
(i) On the roadway side of any vehicle stopped or parked at the edge or curb of a street;
(ii) On a sidewalk or street planting strip;
(iii) Within an intersection;
(iv) On a crosswalk;
(v) Between a safety zone and the adjacent curb or within ((thirty))30 feet of points on the curb immediately opposite the ends of a safety zone, unless official signs or markings indicate a different no-parking area opposite the ends of a safety zone;
(vi) Alongside or opposite any street excavation or obstruction when stopping, standing, or parking would obstruct traffic;
(vii) Upon any bridge or other elevated structure upon a highway or within a highway tunnel;
(viii) On any railroad tracks;
(ix) In the area between roadways of a divided highway including crossovers; or
(x) At any place where official signs prohibit stopping.
(b) Stand or park a vehicle, whether occupied or not, except momentarily to pick up or discharge a passenger or passengers:
(i) In front of a public or private driveway or within five feet of the end of the curb radius leading thereto, except that a city or county may, by ordinance or resolution, allow residential property owners within their jurisdiction to park, or allow another to park, across the point of ingress or egress of the driveway entering on to the residential property, provided that such parking does not obstruct a sidewalk, another driveway, or the roadway;
(ii) Within ((fifteen))15 feet of a fire hydrant;
(iii) Within ((twenty))20 feet of a crosswalk;
(iv) Within ((thirty))30 feet upon the approach to any flashing signal, stop sign, yield sign, or traffic control signal located at the side of a roadway;
(v) Within ((twenty))20 feet of the driveway entrance to any fire station and on the side of a street opposite the entrance to any fire station within ((seventy-five))75 feet of said entrance when properly signposted; or
(vi) At any place where official signs prohibit standing.
(c) Park a vehicle, whether occupied or not, except temporarily for the purpose of and while actually engaged in loading or unloading property or passengers:
(i) Within ((fifty))50 feet of the nearest rail of a railroad crossing; or
(ii) At any place where official signs prohibit parking.
(2) Parking or standing shall be permitted in the manner provided by law at all other places except a time limit may be imposed or parking restricted at other places but such limitation and restriction shall be by city ordinance or county resolution or order of the secretary of transportation upon highways under their respective jurisdictions.
(3) No person shall move a vehicle not lawfully under his or her control into any such prohibited area or away from a curb such a distance as is unlawful.
(4) It shall be unlawful for any person to reserve or attempt to reserve any portion of a highway for the purpose of stopping, standing, or parking to the exclusion of any other like person, nor shall any person be granted such right.
--- END ---
1061.summary:
Purpose

The primary aim of House Bill 1061 is to provide additional parking flexibility in residential neighborhoods by modifying existing parking regulations. Key changes include allowing city or county ordinances that permit residential property owners to park across the point of ingress or egress of their driveways, as long as it does not obstruct sidewalks, other driveways, or the roadway. This change is intended to enhance parking opportunities for residents while ensuring that traffic flow and safety are maintained.

Key Provisions

Parking Regulations

  • No person shall stop, stand, or park a vehicle in certain prohibited areas, including but not limited to:
    • On the roadway side of any parked vehicle.
    • On sidewalks or street planting strips.
    • Within intersections or on crosswalks.
    • Between a safety zone and the curb unless specified by signs.
    • Near street excavations or obstructions in a way that obstructs traffic.
    • On bridges, elevated structures, or within tunnels.
    • On railroad tracks or in divided highway areas.
  • Parking is restricted in front of public or private driveways, but local ordinances may allow property owners to park across their driveways without obstructing sidewalks, other driveways, or roadways.

Specific Distances for Parking

  • Restrictions on standing or parking include:
    • Within 15 feet of a fire hydrant.
    • Within 20 feet of a crosswalk or a traffic control signal.
    • Within 30 feet of the approach to stop or yield signs.
    • Within 20 feet of fire station driveways, with specific distances for the opposite side.

Temporary Parking Exceptions

  • Vehicles may park temporarily for loading or unloading, but not within 50 feet of railroad crossings or in areas with official no-parking signs.

General Parking Permissions

  • Parking or standing is generally permitted in places not specified by law, with limitations potentially imposed by local city ordinances or county resolutions.

Prohibited Moves

  • It is illegal for a person to move a vehicle that they do not control into a prohibited area or to relocate a vehicle too far from a curb unlawfully.

Reservation of Parking

  • Reserving road space for parking exclusively is not allowed, ensuring equal access to road space for all.

1061-S.summary:
Purpose

The edits made to the proposed bill aim to clarify and expand on the parking regulations specific to residential neighborhoods in Washington State. The changes primarily focus on providing greater flexibility for residential property owners concerning parking arrangements. A notable introduction in the edited version is the allowance for property owners to park across their own driveway, provided specific conditions are met. This aims to strike a balance between facilitating parking and maintaining roadway safety.

Key Changes

Specification of Sponsors and Legislative Details

  • The bill is now attributed to "House Transportation" instead of individual sponsors.
  • The "READ FIRST TIME" date has been changed from 01/13/25 to 02/03/25.

Changes in Parking Regulations

  • Adjustments have been made to the allowances for parking in front of driveways:
    • The new version specifies that residential property owners may park across the point of ingress or egress of their driveway, as long as the driveway does not exceed 50 feet and parking does not obstruct sidewalks, another driveway, or the roadway.

Revisions of Measurement Standards

  • All previously stated distances where parking was restricted (e.g., 15 feet from a fire hydrant, 20 feet from a crosswalk) have had their textual references changed from written numbers to numerical forms:
    • "fifteen" to "15"
    • "twenty" to "20"
    • "thirty" to "30"
    • "fifty" to "50"
    • "seventy-five" to "75"

This improves consistency in the document, ensuring that all measurements are uniformly presented.

Additional Notes

Overall, the changes in the edited version enhance the bill's clarity while providing additional allowances for residents, promoting more effective use of parking space while ensuring that safety regulations remain intact.
